gloss: Literally 'entering three points into the wood'; figuratively means profound insight or deep understanding.
teaser: Today, we explore a phrase that highlights the depth of artistic expression.
script: Welcome to Chengyu Bites — your quick summary on Chinese 成语. Today, we explore a phrase that highlights the depth of artistic expression. [break 1s] The phrase is: 入木三分, rù mù sān fēn. [break 1s] 入 (rù) - to enter [break 0.5s] 木 (mù) - wood [break 0.5s] 三 (sān) - three [break 0.5s] 分 (fēn) - points [break 0.5s] The full idiom again: 入木三分. Literally, it means 'entering three points into the wood'; figuratively, it signifies profound insight or deep understanding. [break 1s] Here’s the story behind it: [break 1.5s] This idiom originates from the famous calligrapher Wang Xizhi, who was known for his exceptional skills. It is said that when he wrote, his brush would penetrate the paper so deeply that it appeared to enter the wood beneath. This deep impression left a lasting impression of his skill and insight in art. [break 1.5s] Example 1: 他的评论真是入木三分。 [break 1s] His comments are truly profound. [break 1s] Example 2: 这位作家的作品总能入木三分。 [break 1s] This writer's works always show deep understanding. [break 1s] Example 3: 她的演讲入木三分，打动了每一个人。 [break 1s] Her speech was profound and moved everyone. [break 1s] So, today’s idiom is 入木三分, meaning profound insight or deep understanding. Thank you for listening to Chengyu Bites! See you next time for another idiom. [break 1s]
